claim.text: FEMA P-361, now in its third edition (2015), establishes engineering standards for residential and community safe rooms capable of withstanding EF5 tornado winds — 250 miles per hour
claim.claim: EF5 tornado winds reach 250 miles per hour

results.summary: EF5 tornado wind speeds are defined as exceeding 200 mph, with the upper theoretical bound around 318 mph, but 250 mph represents a reasonable design specification within the EF5 range.
results.detail: The Enhanced Fujita Scale defines EF5 tornadoes as having estimated wind speeds greater than 200 mph (over 200 mph), with no defined upper limit. The claim that EF5 winds 'reach 250 miles per hour' is technically imprecise — EF5 winds START above 200 mph and can theoretically reach higher. However, 250 mph is a commonly used design wind speed for safe rooms in FEMA standards, representing a reasonable upper-bound engineering specification within the EF5 category. The original text's context (FEMA P-361 safe room standards) makes the 250 mph figure appropriate as a design criterion rather than a definition of EF5 winds.
sources: NOAA National Weather Service Enhanced Fujita Scale documentation
FEMA P-361 Safe Room design standards

claim.text: NIST's subsequent investigation found that occupants of reinforced safe rooms and basements with overhead protection survived impacts that destroyed the homes around them
claim.claim: NIST conducted an investigation of the 2011 Joplin tornado

results.summary: NIST did conduct a formal investigation of the 2011 Joplin, Missouri tornado under the National Construction Safety Team Act.
results.detail: NIST deployed a National Construction Safety Team (NCST) to investigate the May 22, 2011 EF5 tornado in Joplin, Missouri. This was the first tornado investigation conducted under the NCST Act. NIST's final report (NIST Technical Note 1753) published in 2014 included findings about the effectiveness of safe rooms and shelter areas, confirming that reinforced safe rooms provided life-saving protection even when the surrounding structures were destroyed.
sources: NIST Technical Note 1753 (2014): Technical Investigation of the May 22, 2011, Tornado in Joplin, Missouri
NIST Disaster and Failure Studies Program records

claim.text: mobile homes account for a disproportionate share of tornado fatalities despite being a smaller fraction of housing stock
claim.claim: Mobile homes account for a disproportionate share of tornado fatalities relative to their share of housing stock

results.summary: Mobile homes account for approximately 40-50% of tornado fatalities while comprising only about 6-7% of U.S. housing stock, a well-documented disproportion.
results.detail: This is a well-established finding in tornado safety research. According to NOAA and the National Weather Service, mobile/manufactured homes consistently account for roughly 40-50% of tornado deaths despite representing only about 6-7% of total U.S. housing units. The Storm Prediction Center and peer-reviewed research in journals like Weather, Climate, and Society have documented this disproportion. The vulnerability stems from mobile homes' lighter construction and lack of anchoring systems compared to site-built homes.
sources: NOAA Storm Prediction Center tornado fatality statistics
National Weather Service tornado safety data
U.S. Census Bureau American Housing Survey (housing stock percentages)
